column4: I asked at one point how to do a clean install of 8.04 without loosing my 7.10 home folder.  someone said to just mount the volume and delete everything but the home folder. Can someone tell me how to do that?
mimi:  look at the fstab.  also locate and install the ntfs 3g configuration via synaptic.

I asked at one point how to do a clean install of 8.04 without loosing my 7.10 home folder.  someone said to just mount the volume and delete everything but the home folder. Can someone tell me how to do that?
mimi:  i said look at it.  but i then said check out the NTFS 3g configuration utility by installing it via synaptic.
mimi:  when you run that tool and set it up, it makes entries in the fstab
mimi:  and those are what is necessary to have the volume mounted upon start up.
mimi:  if that doesn't work you should run the ntfs tools package to run a check against the ntfs volume.  there's a flag that is not set when the volume is not unmounted properly.
mimi:  read the description before you install it.  it lists the various utilities that it installs
ntfs-config allows him to set up the fstab using a gui.  but it won't address the issues of the ntfs mount flag being improperly set.
isn't it ntfsfix without the hyphen, though?
if you go back into synaptic and you look at the ntfsprogs entry, then read the description, you'll see the list of utilities.
I've only had problems having ntfs-3g mount volumes when the ntfs volume hadn't been unmounted cleanly

i understand....the ntfsprogs is the set of utilities designed to help you resolve the unclean mount issue.  you also have the choice of connecting that drive to an windows box and unmounting it that way.
I realise that ntfsprogs pulls several utilities, it's just that ntfsfix in particular is invoked without the hyphen. I think.
just try both and find out which one lists that it needs parameters and which one tells you that it can't find the program you are trying to invoke
only I don't think it was brought up that the volume had been unmounted badly. Might've missed it
